courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Theories of Global Political Economy
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to broad themes, key concepts, and major theories used to understand the global political economy, and how national political-economies fit into the global system. In the first half, we will cover a bit of methodology and the philosophy of science of political economy, the history of the global political-economic system, contemporary controversies, and possible futures. In the second half, we will cover the major theories that scholars have constructed to make sense of the global political economy, including economic nationalism or realism, liberalism, and critical theories. Having prior knowledge of international relations scholarship or economics will help, but is not strictly necessary. The aim of this course is to provide an intellectual foundation for understanding how the world system operates, and for further, more specialized studies in the many areas that GPE covers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Substantive Knowledge:
The “big picture” of what Global Political Economy covers as an academic discipline: interactions between politics and economics, the history and development of political-economic systems, and understanding the contemporary world system.
Students should be conversant with the essential themes, concepts, and terms employed in the study of global political economy.
Familiarity with the major theories that have been constructed to make sense of the global political economy, where they differ and where they overlap, and their strengths and weaknesses.
• Critical Analysis:
Students should be able to identify the central thesis of books or articles, understand how the authors develop and defend it, and critically evaluate the author’s thesis, evidence, and logic.
Students should be able to assess the strength and weaknesses of theories/arguments in GPE and engage in critical discussions and debates.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Methodology and the philosophy of science of political economy
Ontology, epistemology, scientific realism, the artificial divide between politics and economics

2. The history of the global political economy
Deep history, history of economic development, history of the global financial and economic systems

3. Contemporary problems
Financialization, financial reform nationally and internationally

4. The future of political economies
Money and its function in political economy

5. Theories through which to understand the complex system
Economic nationalism/realism, liberalism, critical theories

courses.title: International Financial and Trade Policy: From Bretton Woods to G20/Doha
courses.description:
This course examines the nature, evolution and particularly the ramifications of the Bretton Woods system and institutions, particularly for companies and other organizations operating in Asia. Global financial institutions and especially international trade and investment, their roles and issues, will be explored. This will include recognizing and understanding the characteristics and challenges of trade and investment across borders, and managing the associated opportunities and threats, illustrated by case examples.

The course will begin with an overview of the Bretton Woods system, its rise and fall, and subsequent efforts to manage the global economy. It will discuss the implications of the rules and politics of finance, trade and investment, and issues like globalization, protectionism and the role of foreign direct investment. The focus will be on how international trade and finance rules and particularly policies actually work and don't work for companies and other organizations operating in Asia, with special attention paid to recent developments like the Asia Infrastructure Development Bank, new bilateral and multilateral economic agreements and the evolving role of the G-20.

courses.description: This course consists of two closely interrelated and complementary parts. The aim of the economic part is to describe and explain the origins, forms, and consequences of international investment. Both foreign direct investment (FDI) and international portfolio investment are highlighted, but greater emphasis is placed on the former. The role played by governments and international institutions is accorded considerable attention. The aim of the business part is to describe and explain in an elaborate fashion the role played by multinational/transnational enterprises (MNEs/TNEs), the key players in global business arena, in the world economy. The forces shaping this role and MNEs responses—strategic, tactical, and operational—are highlighted. Regulatory matters are accorded considerable attention.

courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Currency War – Past, Present and Future
courses.description:
The Currency War that erupted in 2010 has weaken the financial foundation of the world’s advanced economies and eroded the currency functions of the three global currencies (the USD, Euro and Japanese yen), or G3 currencies. This has given the Chinese renminbi a window of opportunity to rise and challenge the global dominance of the G3 currencies. This is a structural change that will shake up the global political economy and monetary system in the decades to come by adding a new player – China – to the future currency war. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping is pushing through structural reforms to chase his "Chinese Dream" when the global powers are repositioning to accommodate the renminbi in the global system.

The course will encompass the past, present and future aspects of the currency war by integrating China’s development in the global currency war environment. It will prepare students for understanding the coming changes in Mainland China and how they will affect the global monetary system and political economy. The course will start with some basic economic concepts that are needed to understand the economics part of the course. It will use the currency war development to explain the rise of the renminbi, the political and economic challenges behind the opening up of China and the evolution of China's policy and financial development in shaping the future of the world economy.

The lectures will cover the following topics:
• Theoretical concepts needed to understand and analyse the world’s currency war
• The origin of currency war and economic/policy lessons learnt from experience
• Development of the currency war and the renminbi’s mega trend
• Rotational currency depreciation, an alternative definition of currency war
• Hong Kong and China in currency war
• The rise of the renminbi to challenge the G3 currencies
• Structural drivers that are changing the dynamics behind the G3 currencies and the renminbi
• Erosion of the financial prowess of the advance economies by the currency war and a window of opportunity for the rise of the renminbi
• Currency war prompts renminbi reform
• The advent of the “Impossible Trinity” as the renminbi rises and as China’s capital account opens up
• The political reality and challenges for China to manage the rise of its currency to become a global currency in the currency war environment
• Renminbi internationalisation, progress, challenges, and the next step in the context of the currency war
• China’s Belt and Road initiative and renminbi internationalisation
• Myths, hypes and truth of the Belt and Road initiative
• The future of the renminbi (what will make it a global currency?)

courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Global Energy Markets
courses.description:
Energy drives the modern world. The availability of cheap and plentiful energy such as fossil fuels and nuclear energy has transformed every aspect of human civilization. Electricity and petroleum products such as gasoline, diesel, natural gas, and petrochemical products are essential to the well-functioning of a world economy, and its availability key to lifting a country out of poverty. News headlines are often dominated by energy issues which include energy shortages and disruptions, spiking gasoline and diesel prices at the pump, acute electricity generation crisis in many developed countries, and unaffordable energy prices for developing countries, all with highly relevant political and economic consequences. Global energy instability is likely to be a paramount political issue of our time in the foreseeable future.

This course aims to provide a rigorous and systemic overview and understanding of global energy markets, one of the most complex and capital-intensive economic systems in the world. This course teaches the basic language of energy and its measurements; supply/demand balance and what it means; how the various energy markets work and their interconnectedness; issues driving energy market trends and disruptions; and the critical and emerging issues that will impact these markets.

This course offers a balanced and realistic understanding of energy issues, primarily with fact and data-based information and insights, aided by the introduction of powerful frameworks to help illuminate these topics and challenge conventional wisdom or myths. The course aims to enlighten understanding and discussion of energy market issues that will continue to dominate news headlines.

Students should have an open mind and be creative. Active participation in class discussion is highly encouraged. Never hesitate to interrupt the instructor in the classroom. The instructor welcomes questions and appreciates challenges. The hope is that students will have fun in taking the course and get more interested in the topics after one semester.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to acquire an informed and fact-based view of the global world energy economy, which includes:

1. Understanding key factors that drive energy market behaviour including resource, technological, economic and political drivers.
2. Ability to analyse, evaluate and compare various energy resources.
3. Understanding energy policy choices for countries and the factors that drive them, and;
4. Ability to understand basic energy market dynamics and generalize the principles that drive their individual evolution and fuel competition.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module 1: The Global Energy Economy – an overview (3 weeks)

Week 1: The importance and role of global energy economy in the world; introduction of the structure and language of the energy economy -why is energy so important economically?
Learning focus: Impact of energy on economic and human development; the language of energy; measurement and conversion of measurement units; supply/demand framework and its elements
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: Relationship between energy and economic development, can one do without the other?

Week 2: Understanding Energy supply demand balance and key energy markets
Learning focus: World energy supply demand balance; energy trade flows- imports and exports; the meaning of self-sufficiency; prices of energy
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: How much energy do we use and how extensively?

Week 3: Review of supply demand balance for specific countries and their policy implications.
Learning focus: Review of the energy economy for several countries and their implications:
Concepts for case studies and discussion: why is nature so unfair? The meaning of self-sufficiency.

Module 2: Petroleum: Oil and Natural Gas (4 weeks)

Week 1: Petroleum Exploration and Production (E&P)
Learning focus: basics processes of E&P; resource and reserves – physical and economic; technological innovation – horizontal drilling and fracking; crude oil versus natural gas; E&P transportation
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: Is Peak oil a reality - are we running out of oil?

Week 2: Refining & transportation of refined products- the black box that means everything
Learning focus: Crude types, overview of refining process; refining economics; product transportation
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: The black box - why don’t politicians understand how gasoline prices are set?

Week 3: Transportation fuels and petrochemicals- the foundation of a modern economy. What are petroleum products used for?
Learning focus: Supply chain for petroleum products; markets for gasoline, diesel, jet fuel; petrochemicals and their use; substitutes for petroleum products; biofuels.
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: why are petrol prices so high in Hong Kong?

Week 4: Natural gas and its use – from heating to electricity generation? The clean fuel of the future?
Learning focus: Natural production; transport and storage of natural gas; Key markets segments for natural gas – heating and cooking, electricity generation and fertilizers; pricing of natural gas.
Concepts for case studies and tutorial discussion: The story of fracking.

Module 3: electricity generation and markets (4 weeks)

Week 1: Electricity sector overview:
Learning focus: generation, transmission, and distribution; grid management, markets for electricity and pricing; regulation of electricity markets
Concept for case studies and tutorial discussion: Load profile of electricity - how do we solve the mismatch of generation and consumption?

Week 2: All about coal - dirty, abundant, and indispensable?
Learning focus: resource base of coal; coal quality, production process and supply chain; coal prices, air pollution and clean coal technology; CO 2 emissions; market segments for coal; world’s largest users of coal.
Concept for case studies and tutorial discussion: can we get rid of coal?

Week 3: Nuclear energy overview – whither the future?
Learning focus: Nuclear energy production; nuclear technologies; nuclear accidents, regulations, and cost of nuclear plants; emerging technologies;
Concept for case studies and tutorial discussion: Nuclear technology future – why has not there been a technological breakthrough in energy since Star Trek?
Week 4: Hydro and Renewables: Ready for prime time?
Learning focus: Overview of hydro, solar and wind energy; growth of solar and wind energy; economics of renewable energy, storage of intermittent energy; impact of climate change on renewable energy growth

courses.title: Theories and Practice of International Law
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the system of international law that has emerged over the past few centuries. We will examine its historical development, contemporary structure, and content: the law of war, humanitarian and human rights law, international criminal law, treaties, environmental law, and law governing world trade. This course aims at providing basic knowledge and familiarity with important legal institutions and principles, and an understanding of the power and limitations of law. As an introductory course, no prior knowledge is strictly required. This course is related to several other areas of GPE, since law provides an essential part of the institutional infrastructure of the world system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Substantive Knowledge:
The basic structure of international law: its sources, organizations, applications, and enforcement mechanisms
How law affects and influences political and economic decisions by states and policymakers
• Critical Analysis:
Students should be able to perform basic legal analysis, judging whether a particular state action or policy is legal under international law, and whether its legality or illegality is of practical import.
Students should be able to incorporate legal analysis into their understanding of other aspects of global political economy, from economic to foreign policy
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The historical development of international law and organizations
From the Treaty of Westphalia to the United Nations; common law and civil law traditions

2. Contemporary international legal organizations
The UN and its bodies; the ICC; ICJ; WTO; ECHR, IACHR etc.

3. The law of war
Jus ad bellum, jus in bello, just war theory, enforcement, novel issues

4. Humanitarian and human rights law
Civil, political, economic, social, and cultural rights; humanitarian intervention

5. International criminal law
ICC, universal jurisdiction, controversy

6. Law governing world trade, environmental law
WTO, TRIPS, climate change and pollution controls

courses.title: Political Psychology for Global Political Economy
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the hybrid field of political psychology – a cross between social psychology and political science – focusing particularly on its areas of overlap with the traditional concerns of GPE. We will examine evolutionary psychology and the psychological underpinnings of political-economic ideology; the psychological dynamics of propaganda and public opinion; the psychology of radicalization and terrorism; national identity and other forms of identity; and economic psychology. As an introductory course, no prior knowledge is strictly required, although prior study in social psychology will be helpful. This course is indirectly related to aspects of international relations, but for the most part it provides a very different approach to issues in GPE.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Substantive Knowledge:
Key theories in political psychology and their relevance for an understanding of GPE
How the experimental method of political psychology can inform a systemic understanding of political-economic concerns
• Critical Analysis:
Students should be able to critique individual experiments and political-psychological theories, and incorporate their findings and conclusions within a system-level understanding of the global political economy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Evolutionary psychology and the psychological underpinnings of political-economic ideology
The evolutionary algorithm; how evolutionary history made its mark on human psychology; the psychological correlates of political-economic ideology

2. The psychological dynamics of propaganda and public opinion
How the human mind processes information; psychological biases; propaganda, PR, and persuasion; influences on public opinion

3. The psychology of radicalization and terrorism
What motivates radicalization and terrorism; ideational and emotional influences; reforming former terrorists

4. National identity and other forms of identity
What is national identity, and how do different people conceptualize it; quality/complexity of thought and identity; overlapping identities; ingroup and outgroup bias

5. Economic psychology
Behavioral economics; how human psychology affects economic processes

courses.title: Global Citizenship
courses.description:
The course explores the conceptual understanding and issues related to global citizenship in contemporary societies. Using relevant theories and perspectives, students will be engaged in discussing the construction and development of the ideas and values on global citizen and global communities, which have been brought about by rapid globalization progresses and social changes.
Topics under discussion include the notions and debates on global citizenship, relationship between individuals and global communities, ethics and concerns on global citizenship and global sustainability and wellbeing. By adopting socio-cultural, political and economic lens, students will be provided with an opportunity to reflect the in-depth meaning of a global citizen and their ways in contributing a better world.

courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, the students will be able to:

1. Demonstrate a conceptual understanding of global citizenship and its relevant theories and concepts.
2. Discuss how the ideas and debates of global citizenship affect world political, economic, social and cultural issues.
3. Examine the development and importance of global communities and its linkage to individuals.
4. Reflect on different perspectives and insights of global citizenship for promoting global sustainability and wellbeing.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Citizenship and global citizenship: definitions, concepts, meanings, support and critiques.
2. Study of global citizenship: ethics, cosmopolitanism, diversity, multiculturism and global communities.
3. World issues related to global citizenship: healthy society, wealth and poverty, crime and security, consumerism and human impact on the environment.
4. Global citizenship in action: empathetic citizen, rights and duties, identity, agency and power.

courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Social Innovation: A Changemaker’s Tool
courses.description:
The world is currently faced with many complex and interrelated socio-economic challenges that cannot be solved effectively either by government effort or market forces. Welfare services struggle to cope with budgetary constraints. 1.3 billion people are still living in the dark without electricity. 345 million people in 82 countries are facing acute food insecurity. When existing political economy framework doesn’t seem to be able to tackle these issues, we need new and innovative strategies to address the unmet social needs.

Social innovation is the “reconfiguring of social practices, in response to societal challenges, which seeks to enhance outcomes on societal well-being and necessarily includes the engagement of civil society actors”. It intends to transform sustainably existing institutions, power structure, and social relations from a bottom-up collective agency approach. A successful social innovation is supposed to be more effective, efficient and sustainable in creating a community resilient to challenges that is based on social justice and mutual respect and through citizen involvement. It is a community with new forms of collaboration, improved capabilities, more equal power relations, and a better use of societal resources. If social innovation is embedded in our societies, our social life, in the end, will be transformed.

By the end of the course, students should have a good understanding of the basic principles of social innovation. You will be able to complete a social innovation proposal and accomplish the following tasks: 1) to understand how to analyze why certain social issues cannot be effectively solved; 2) to use knowledge and skills developed in class to design an innovative solution; 3) to provide critical peer evaluation on other groups’ projects; and 4) to have insights on how to embed social innovation in your future career.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Being able to utilize basic concepts related to the field of social innovation
2. Being able to understand the values and beliefs behind the social innovation paradigm
3. Being able to analyze complex issues from the social innovation perspective
4. Be familiar with the process of generating innovative solutions

courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Trade in Turmoil: Evolution of the Global Trade System and Implications for Today
courses.description: The course explores the root causes of the current turmoil in global trade by examining the founding and subsequent evolution of the rules-based trade system in the aftermath of the Second World War. Students will be challenged to “connect the dots” between the current dysfunction which riddles the system and the mistaken assumptions and strategic miscalculations that have been made over the decades. Topics under discussion will include paralysis in the World Trade Organization, the rise of protectionism and “worker-centric” policies, trade fragmentation and so-called “friendshoring”, the challenges of rapid technological advancement and trade governance, the rise of the global South, and the points of trade friction between the US and China. By diving deeply into the root causes, students will gain a “real world” perspective on the trade issues dominating global headlines.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:

1. To develop an understanding of how the modern international trading system developed and articulate its current strengths and weaknesses.
2. Formulate effective strategies and policies on behalf of their company or organization which reflect the new, emerging realities in the global trade system.
3. Develop a framework for understanding the key issues, challenges, and trends that are likely to shape the global trade system over the next 5 years or so.
4. Discuss and analysis the most important trade issues and initiatives currently unfolding.
5. Assess the impact of trade agreements and understand the mechanics of trade governance.

Lecture 1: Trade in turmoil: taking stock of where we are today

Lecture 4: The rise of protectionism and systemic fragmentation

Lecture 10: Middle powers in an evolving global trade system

courses.title: Political Economy and Foreign Policy of the United States
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the United States’ political economy (how the political and economic systems are structured and how they influence each other) and foreign policy (influences, goals, and means of attaining goals). We will examine the historical development of US political economy and foreign policy, from the American Revolution to modern day, and look at indications of possible future developments. This will include: the structure of the US political-economic system, including law, business, government, media, and society (including public opinion). This course aims at providing a deep understanding of the US government and society, helping to make sense of domestic political developments and the US role on the world stage. No prior knowledge is strictly required, though introductory courses to IR and GPE will be helpful. This course is related to courses analyzing the political economies of other countries and regions, and to comparative politics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Substantive Knowledge:

The “big picture” of the United States’ society and government: how politics and economics intertwine and influence each other, the history and development of the United States and its role in the world, and understanding the contemporary U.S.

The structure of the U.S. government and legal system, and an overview of its economy

How U.S. foreign policy is determined and implemented

• Critical Analysis:

Students should be able to identify the central thesis of books or articles, understand how the authors develop and defend it, and critically evaluate the author’s thesis, evidence, and logic.

Students should be able to draw comparisons between facets of the US political economy and those of other countries, and understand how structure influences outcomes
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The history and development of the US state and society

Ideational and material factors jointly influencing development; how economics influenced politics (and vice versa) over time

2. The history of US foreign policy

Ideologies, policies, influences, and actions over US history

3. The contemporary United States

The political, legal, and economic systems; elections; media and society; the Republican and Democratic Parties

4. Contemporary US foreign policy

How “national security” and “national interest” are determined, who/what influences foreign policy, how are goals attained

5. Possible future developments

Economic changes; suggestive signs of political and ideological evolution

courses.subject: GPEC
courses.title: Chinese Foreign Policy
courses.description:
This course is designed to survey and analyze Chinese foreign policy. In particular, the course examines China’s rise as a global power and its new roles in the international system.

This course begins with a review of the main drivers of China’s foreign policymaking. It will then explore the myth and reality of China’s rise as well as its grand strategies since the 1990s. The course will also analyze China’s relations with other great powers such as the United States, Russia, Japan and India, as well as its involvements with Asia’s hot spots of conflicts, such as the South China Sea and the Korean Peninsula. Finally, the course will explore China’s new roles in world affairs to determine whether it is a revisionist or responsible rising power.

courses.title: Contemporary Chinese Society
courses.description:
China has embarked her economic reforms since the late 1970s when Deng Xiaoping initiated the “Reform and Open Door” policy. The economic transformation over the last four decades has been remarkable and significant. The most notable one is the successful transformation of a centralized and a planned economy into a market (non-market) one. Moreover, China joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002 to engage fully with the globalization trend. With these internal and external backdrops, contemporary Chinese society has been undergoing many changes, facing challenges and having abundant opportunities too. In this course, several contemporary salient issues will be focused such as higher education, inequality, migration, aging, corruption and health, among others. Their causes, problems, consequences and implications will be examined within the framework of state-society relationship.
Last, but not least, discussions will be encouraged in the class. The dialogue should provide an excellent forum for students to engage in an active mode of learning. Ideas can be tested; points will be made, and, above all, judgements will be formed. This will further cultivate a sense of intellectual dialogue within a productive and an encouraging environment.

courses.title: Greater China in the Global Political Economy
courses.description:
As the world’s second largest economy and biggest trading nation, China is pursuing a multi-pronged strategy to enhance its role in the global political economy. While the quasi-superpower’s goals are focused on attaining a bigger say in reshaping the international financial architecture, its voice is being heard on issues ranging from Free Trade Agreements and commodity prices to climate change and food security. Under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, Beijing is packing a bigger punch in institutions and forums including the International Monetary Fund as well as the G20 and APEC. Moreover, the Xi administration is trying to buttress China’s global influence through overarching undertakings such as the “One Belt, One Road” or the Belt and Road Initiative (B&RI) to nurture cross-border and inter-continental infrastructure projects. The Belt and Road grand plan will also showcase China’s aggressive Outbound Foreign Direct Investment (OFDI) strategy as well as the country’s leaps-and-bounds advancement in high technology. In the course of the teaching and discussion, ample weight will be given to the roles of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau, which are substantial players within the “Greater China” universe.

Apart from analyzing world-sized projects and activities involving the Belt and Road, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, the G20 as well as UN institutions, this course will examine China’s relations with major countries and regions, particularly the U.S., Russia, Japan, the two Koreas, India, the ASEAN and EU from the global political-economy perspective. A common theme will be to appraise the extent to which Beijing can sell its “win-win” scenarios in trade, investment and security-related cooperation to global partners. The Xi administration, however, has to counter the “anti-China containment policy” supposedly being spearheaded by countries including the U.S., India, Japan, Vietnam and Australia. Beijing must also reassure developed countries that it is not stealing their technologies through M&A operations – and developing nations that it is not pursuing neo-colonialist agendas.

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) administration’s ability to win over countries and regions and to enlarge its global footprint depends, however, on the viability of the “China model.” Whether China can modernize government institutions and corporate governance – and raise the competitiveness of its industrial and services sectors – is pivotal to its objective of becoming a norm-setter in the global political economy. These important issues will be analyzed and discussed in class after students have gained a good understanding of the Chinese economic structure, the country’s foreign-policy and national-security priorities, and latest developments in the global political economy.

courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1. CHINA’S CONCERNS AND STRATEGIES IN MAJOR ARENAS OF THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY
The lecture and class discussion will focus on how China the fast-rising quasi-superpower is boosting its clout in the global political economy through major initiatives in diplomacy, national security, and international economics and finance.
The Xi Jinping administration's new priorities on different aspects of state security -- including financial, energy and environmental security -- will be examined. Particular attention will be paid to China’s diplomatic and economic relations with powers and blocs including the United States, the EU, Japan, Russia, ASEAN, and world bodies such as the UN, the IMF, and the G20.

Topic 2. CHINA’S ECONOMICS-BASED DIPLOMACY AND OUTBOUND FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT (OFDI); THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE “BELT AND ROAD INITIATIVE”
Beijing has since the 2000s sought to use its economic heft and influence as diplomatic tools to improve its relations with "peripheral states" and great powers alike.
The Xi Jinping administration’s employment of economic inducements such as overseas development aid and outbound foreign direct investment (OFDI) will be studied. Discussion will be held over the execution of China's economics-based diplomacy in selected theatres such as ASEAN, Africa as well as the U.S. and the EU. Assessment will be made of the efficacy of the “One Belt, One Road” game plan.
Students are encouraged to make suggestions as to how Beijing can better utilize OFDI and related strategies to win friends and neutralize enemies. Emphasis will be put on agendas including securing reliable supplies of energy and other resources; procuring high technology; and marketing Chinese products and know-how including high-speed railways.

Topic 3. FOCUS ON THE CHALLENGES OF THE “BELT AND ROAD INITIATIVE”
An assessment of the significance of the Belt and Road Initiative in view of comparative global undertakings such as the Marshall Plan in post-WWII Europe. Questions will be asked about whether Beijing is shouldering most of the investment burden given lackluster response from the U.S. and the EU. Thorough appraisals will be made of the long-term viability of multi-billion-dollar projects in Pakistan and Sri Lanka, which bear the hallmark of overseas development aid (ODA). Also discussed will be foreign economists’ views that Beijing’s commitments to big projects in Asia and Africa will exacerbate China’s already serious debt problems. Comparisons will be made between the B&RI and the Asia African Growth Corridor sponsored by Japan and India.

Topic 4. CHINA, THE G20 AND BEIJING’S EFFORTS TO RESHAPE THE GLOBAL FINANCIAL ARCHITECTURE
Beijing has since the global financial crisis of 2008 sought to play a more assertive role in reshaping the international financial architecture. The Xi administration's strategies and performance in global forums such as the G20 will be assessed. Students will be asked to discuss major Chinese goals ranging from promoting the global status of the renminbi to ensuring fair trade particularly with the developed world. Also analyzed will be Beijing efforts together with other BRICS members to ensure that major developing countries will have a bigger say in reforming the global financial infrastructure. The long-term significance of the Asian Infrastructure Development Bank – and its perceived challenges to the Asian Development Bank and the IMF – will be appraised.

Topic 5. GLOBAL INTERACTIONS: FTAs, FOOD SECURITY, COMMODITY PRICING AND CLIMATE CHANGE
The lecture and discussion will focus on China the assertive international actor in areas including the formation of free trade agreements and trade pacts with countries ranging from ASEAN members to Central Asian states. Also analyzed will be China’s efforts in engaging in global solutions relating to urgent tasks such as boosting food supplies, reducing carbon emissions, and promoting green energy solutions. Comparisons will be made between the Beijing-initiated Regional Comprehensive Economic Pact (RCEP) and the half-defunct Transpacific Partnership (TPP) spearheaded by the Obama administration. Emphasis will be put on how Beijing can prove itself as a responsible stakeholder if not a leader in the solution of global problems and the provision of global public goods. The fact that the Trump administration has displayed an anti-globalization stance – and Washington’s pulling out of the Paris Accord – has afforded the Xi administration new opportunities of demonstrating China’s commitment to globalization and to becoming a rule-setter in international intercourse.

Topic 6. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-U.S. RELATIONS
After examining the voluminous literature (in both English and Chinese) on Sino-U.S. relations since WWII, this class will discuss new challenges on the trade and foreign-policy fronts in the Xi Jinping and Donald Trump administrations. The traditionally win-win, symbiotic economic ties between the two giants could be jeopardized by security challenges epitomized by the North Korea crisis. One example is whether Trump could use trade-related threats to force Beijing to use more forceful means to restrain Pyongyang’s nuclear program. Also analyzed will be the role of Taiwan in complicating Sino-U.S. relations from the global political-economy perspective.

Topic 7. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-RUSSIAN RELATIONS
The lecture and class discussion will focus on the global political economy factors behind the quasi-alliance relationship between China and Russia. For geopolitical and security reasons, both leaderships have developed a strong bondage based on their mutual concern about countering the American threat. Relevant IR theories will be explored to discuss the common China-Russian front on the North Korean issue. Manifestations of China-Russia cooperation in the form of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization will be assessed. However, these two former Cold War
adversaries also harbor deep-seated distrusts over issues such as China’s economic predominance: Central Asia, hitherto Russia’s backyard, has become a Chinese economic sphere of interest particularly in the wake of the R&BI.

Topic 8. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA’S RELATIONS WITH THE TWO KOREAS AND WITH JAPAN
The North Korean missile and nuclear crisis has thrown into sharp perspective the convoluted quadrangular relations between China, the two Koreas, and Japan. What are the historical – and geopolitical – reasons behind Beijing’s refusal to jettison or at least curtail its alliance relationship with the DPRK? Questions of history as well as disputes over several pieces of rocks (called the Diaoyus or Senkakus) have put obstacles in the way of a symbiotic economic relationship between China and Japan. Discussion will be informed by latest research on the rich but complicated traditions of China-Korean and China-Japanese ties.

Topic 9. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-INDIAN RELATIONS
Despite exceptionally fast growth in bilateral trade in the past decade, Beijing and New Delhi are locked in dispute over border rows – as well as suspicions of each other’s “containment policies.” China and India, however, are important members of the BRICS group, as well as the Shanghai Cooperation Organization. China-India ties thus offer plentiful illustration of the interaction of potential economic symbiosis juxtaposed against increasingly ferocious geopolitical contest.

Topic 10. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-ASEAN RELATIONS
China scored a major victory on the global political economy front when the Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Hague ruled against her claims on the South China Sea in 2016 – and nothing seemed to happen. Most ASEAN states are beholden to China due to massive trade and investment benefits emanating from their “win-win scenarios” with China. That Beijing can still hang on to its claims relating to the “nine dash lines” demonstrates the limits of international law in restricting the behaviors of a rising quasi-superpower.

Topic 11. THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY PERSPECTIVE OF CHINA-EU RELATIONS
Although French President Emmanuel Macron has warned against Chinese firms acquiring high-tech EU manufacturers, Beijing’s buying power – and geopolitical clout – is such that it is picking up not only tech companies but also ports and mines in Europe. Beijing is also accused of “divide and rule” tactics through its special relationship with the 16 central and east European members of the EU (the so-called “16+1 cooperation”). The class will examine the obstacles that Beijing faces in its effort to use its new-found affinity with the EU to hedge against “American neo-imperialism.”

Topic 12. THE VIABILITY AND FUTURE OF “THE CHINESE MODEL”
There is an intimate connection between China's domestic economic and political achievements on the one hand, and its status and game plans in the global political economy on the other. How viable and sustainable is the "China model" -- here understood as not only the country's unique path to economic growth but also the convoluted trajectory of economic and political reforms? The lecture and discussion will focus on reforms introduced by the Hu Jintao and Xi Jinping administrations – and how they impact on China's ability to make a difference on the world stage.

Topic 13. CHINA’S WORLD COMPETITIVENESS, THE “SILICON VALLEY” MODEL, AND “MADE IN CHINA 2025” INITIATIVE
Following the discussion in the previous class on the "China model," this lecture will discuss China's global competitiveness. Students are encouraged to assess the country's unique formula for promoting innovation in government institutions and businesses, including state-own-enterprise conglomerates as well as private firms. Can China nurture a "Silicon Valley with Chinese characteristics"? The successful globalization of a selective number of enterprises ranging from Huawei and Haier to Baidu and Alibaba will be analyzed. Premier Li Keqiang’s ambitious “Made in China 2025” program will be examined. Also analyzed will be the diplomatic functions of leading Chinese multinationals as well as their growing international responsibilities.

Topic 14. REVISIONS OF HIGHLIGHTS OF THE COURSE AND PREDICTIONS OF THE TRAJECTORY OF CHINA’S RISING CLOUT IN THE GLOBAL POLITICAL ECONOMY

courses.title: Non-traditional Security: Terrorism, Corruption and Trans-border Crime
courses.description: This course introduces the concept of terrorism, crime, and corruption. It examines the relations among terrorism, crime, corruption, politics, and economy. Students are encouraged to discuss the impact of terrorism and crime on international and regional stability. The course investigates how governments’ tolerance and intolerance of illicit activities are affected by their impacts on economic growth and self-interests of political elites. Special attention will be focused on the responses of International Organizations and nations on the issues and evaluation of their success and limitations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1) State the definitions of terrorism, crime and corruption.
2) Analyze the ambiguities of these concepts and the consequential state efforts in anti-terrorism, crime and corruption.
3) Explain under what circumstances the states fight, tolerate, and/ or sponsor terrorism, crime and corruption.
4) Compare significant cases of terrorism, crime and corruption.
5) Reflect the contributions and limitations of International Organizations and states in fighting terrorism, crime and corruption.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture 1 Background: What are terrorism, crimes and corruption?
Definitions of terrorism, crimes and corruptions and the difficulties in defining the concepts

Lecture 2 Terrorism, crime and corruption: A global overview.
The factors favourable for terrorists and criminals to expand their global networks; the relations between global terrorism and domestic terrorist activities.

Lecture 3 Roots of terrorism, crime and corruption
The political, economic, cultural, and ideological reasons for the rise of terrorism.

Lecture 4 Government, terrorists and criminals
The reasons for states to fight, tolerate, and/ or even sponsor terrorism, crime and corruption.

Lecture 5 Terrorism in China
The reasons for terrorism in China; the reasons for Chinese government to label the violence in Xinjiang, not other provinces terrorist attacks?

Lecture 6 Corruption in China
The political, economic, cultural, and ideological reasons for corruption in China; the reasons for the success and limitations of the efforts in fighting corruption.

Lecture 7 Crime and corruption in Hong Kong
The cross-border crimes and corruption between China and Hong Kong; the relations between Hong Kong as a financial hub and money laundering in Greater China.

Lecture 8 Casinos and money-laundering in Macao
The roles of Macao’s casinos in China’s law and order, and state-sanctioned terrorism in North Korea.

Lecture 9 Terrorism in the United States
The background of 9/11 attack and the aftermath; the anti-terrorist measures and their effects.

Lecture 10 Terrorism in Europe
The IRA in UK, ETA in Spain, and the Muslim attack; the anti-terrorist measures and their effects

Lecture 11 Terrorism in Middle East
The role of religion in mobilizing terrorist attacks; the terrorism in Israel.

Lecture 12 International efforts in fighting terrorism, crime, and corruption
The roles of UN, EU, and SCO and their success in fighting terrorism, crime, and corruption.

Lecture 13 Conclusion

courses.title: Taiwan’s China Dilemma and Cross-Strait Economic Policy
courses.description: The course examines the political economic relationship between Taiwan and China, focusing on the fundamental role of Taiwan’s evolving national identity in shaping its economic policy towards China. This course analyzes the controversies over Taiwan’s liberalization of its trade and investment relations with the Chinese economy. The course will draw on theories of international political economy and comparative political economy, and on the role of national identity in formulating foreign economic policy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to survey several topics and disciplines including the liberalization of cross-Strait economic relations, theories of international trade and investment, the role of identity and various analytical perspectives on cross-Strait relations. Students will have become familiar with the history of Taiwan and the broader context of cross-Strait relations as well as relevant theories of political economy. In this course, students will analyze in more detail the linkage between economic policy and identity be examining the history of Taiwan-China economic relations from 1990 onwards. Relevant theories of comparative political economy and international political economy and identity will be applied to the case of Taiwan’s economic liberalization towards China. Comparisons will also be made to other countries.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Taiwan’s history and evolution of its history
History of Taiwan, economic miracle, democratic transformation, nation-building, identity

Part II: Cross-Strait relations
Cross-Strait economic policy, economic integration, Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangle

Part III: Taiwan and High-income Trap
Economic liberalization, High-income Trap, inequality, aging society, financialization

courses.title: Race, Sex and Social Class: A Cultural Psychology of the North-South Divide
courses.description: Why do most societies around the world positively discriminate light-skinned, but negatively discriminate dark-skinned people? Why do social norms often restrict the freedoms of certain social identities, such as women? Why is the Global North rich but the Global South poor? This course tries to answer questions such as these by delving deeper into the roots of global inequality. In particular, it will focus on the interactive nature of the relationship between the individual (psychological level) and the social context that maintains social inequality. The course draws heavily from a multidisciplinary body of scholarship to shed light on the multilevel predictors of social inequality including, but not limited to, the global level (e.g., imperialism/(neo-)colonialism, globalization, the international media), the cultural level (e.g., neoliberalism, individualism/collectivism, racism/white supremacy), and the individual level (e.g., social dominance orientation, microaggressions, the self-concept), and how all levels mutually constitute each other. The course heavily emphasizes the Global North vs. South regional differences and attempts to highlight the subjective nature of unequal human relationships. As such, it adopts a critical approach that attempts to break with mainstream hegemonic conceptions of social inequality that often misrepresent it as natural, stable and fixed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSSc in Global Political Economy (MGPE) students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand the deep connection between social inequality on the global level (macro), Group level (meso) and individual level (micro).
* Appreciate and understand how the systemic nature of social inequality makes it an inextricable part of culture.
* Promote an understanding of the “marginalized experience”, that is the reality of people who are part of disadvantaged identities, as it relates to cultural psychology
* Develop an approach to scholarship that integrates Non-Western epistemologies (“ways of knowing”).
* Develop an awareness of the sociohistorical and cultural foundations at the root of modern-day social identities and their unequal relationships.
* Understand that hegemony extends beyond geopolitics into the realm of academia (e.g., Eurocentric perspectives).
* Understand the importance of diverse perspectives for the social sciences.
* Develop critical thinking skills that will facilitate further learning and reasoning.
* Practice basic writing skills related to grammar, clarity, and style.
courses.course_syllabus:
To do justice to the complexity of social inequality, instead of discussing them separately, each

lecture heavily emphasizes the interactive nature of all three of the following levels:

1. Social Inequality at the global level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the cultural and individual levels).

a. Imperialism and colonialism at the root of the unequal contemporary world order (e.g., Global South vs.

Global North).

b. Neo-colonialism reproducing and maintaining the current world order.

i. Export of Western (neo)liberal “free market” capitalism.

ii. Racial Capitalism: How the construction of “race” is necessary to maintain and reproduce economic surplus

in the capitalist core (i.e.., The West).

iii. Hard power (e.g., Militarism, economic warfare/sanctions).

iv. Soft power (e.g., media, religion, education, social media, consumerism).

2. Social Inequality at the cultural level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the global and individual levels).

a. Cultural ideologies: White Supremacy; Individualism; Neoliberalism; Liberalism/Conservatism;

Racism; Islamophobia/Antisemitism; Sexism; Globalization.

b. Social class: socioeconomic status; race; sex; ethnicity; caste.

3. Social Inequality at the individual level (and its reciprocal relationship with inequality at the global and cultural levels).

a. Internalized colonialism (colonial mentality); intersectionality; internalized/externalized racism and sexism;

stereotyping; poverty and executive functioning; the self-concept; microaggressions; political ideology; social

norms/morality; Social Dominance Orientation; Right-Wing Authoritarianism.

Finally, the CUHK’s Course Teaching Evaluation (CCTE) will be closely scrutinized for constructive criticisms for future classes.

courses.description: This course provides an opportunity for students to gain policy research experience working under a supervisor at a partnering organization in or beyond CUHK that is endorsed by the course coordinator. Over the course of the semester, students will contribute to an ongoing research project (topics vary annually), by performing policy-relevant research, surveying/canvassing, and/or data analysis. Each student is assigned a supervisor who will provide instruction, guidance, and assistance during the internship period. Students are required to submit a final report demonstrating the knowledge outcomes attained: for instance, background knowledge acquisition, experience in practical application of theory, data gathering, and data analysis. The student’s performance will be evaluated on the basis of his/ her final report and the supervisor’s assessment. This course is most similar to Independent Research (GPEC5850); the primary difference is that the focus of this course is on applied research, working with a team and supervised by a leading member of the partnering organizations concerned, while the focus of Independent Research can be more theoretical (e.g., literature review and analysis/interpretation) and is done independently under the supervision of a member of the MGPE teaching staff.
